results.title: Hopi Indians: arts and crafts
results.brief_description: Looks at the arts and crafts of the Hopi Indians focusing on weaving, silversmithing, basket making and pottery. Records the skill and patience required in these rapidly disappearing arts.

results.title: Hope Street (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Ivan Hexter and East West Films
results.brief_description: Homelessness is a major dilemma for many young Australians. Through the experiences of several young characters living in a refuge, caravan park and squat, Hope Street explores the reasons for their homelessness, the impact it has on their lives and the ways in which these young people endeavour to resolve their predicaments.

results.title: Hong Kong: far eastern outpost of the empire
results.brief_description: Gives a brief history of the British colony, followed by scenes of the harbour with its houseboats and junks, the farmlands with traditional farming methods, shops and houses, and the streets full of people.

results.title: Honey harvest
results.creator_credit: Norman A. Uren, Department of Agriculture Western Australia and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description: Shows the gathering of honey from wildflowers. It is a seasonal activity and beekeepers move the hives to follow the honey flow throughout the state. The film depicts the extraction of honey, packing and bulk handling. Honey is loaded at Fremantle and shipped overseas. Commercial uses of honey are also indicated.

results.title: Honey bees and pollination
results.creator_credit: J.V. Durden, Larry Gosnell, David Bairstow and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A color film showing the relationship between the activity of bees and the fertility of field and orchard crops. Much of the film is in close-up so that the process of cross-pollination of flowers by bees can be clearly observed. The life of the hive is similarly illustrated, including the peculiar dance by which a successful bee tells the others where its source of honey is located. The film warns that indiscriminate use of chemical sprays may destroy bees, with consequent loss of fertility in crops.

results.title: Homes around the world
results.brief_description: Illustrates the kinds of homes built in different regions of the world depending upon the climate and upon the materials available for building. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Homelands
results.creator_credit: Tom Zubrycki, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Maria and Carlos are a Salvadorean couple living in Melbourne, refugees from the coup d’etat of 1979 and the subsequent civil war. Like many refugees, when peace returns to their home country, they are caught in the dilemma of deciding where they want to live and where they ultimately belong. Carlos chooses to go back immediately to help rebuild his country. Maria and their four children decide to remain in Australia. Six months later, Maria decides to re-visit El Salvador, both to find Carlos and to confront her past. Zubrycki’s closeness to the family, developed over the course of the year he spent filming them, results in an unusually intimate portrayal of domestic tensions.

results.title: Home of the homeless
results.creator_credit: Arthur Zegart and United Nations. Dept. of Public Information
results.brief_description: A story of life in an IRO Displaced Persons’ Camp in Germany. Housed in an old Nazi army barrack, the people live from day to day, always hoping that some country will accept them as immigrants. The film captures the austere living conditions in the camp and the frustration and lonliness of the people. In spite of frequent disappointments, most people have not given up hope of finding a home and useful work. Narrated by Henry Fonda.

results.title: Home of the brave (1986)
results.creator_credit: Laurie Anderson, Paula Mazur and Talk Normal Productions
results.brief_description: Neither a feature film or documentary, “Home of the brave” is a concert film, essentially a record of Laurie Anderson’s “Mister Heartbreak” tour of 1986. Joined by some exemplary performers, Anderson’s legendary show combines computer synthesized music, video, slides and provocative monologues. Having an international reputation since the 1970’s for her use of cutting edge technology in her avant garde performances and music, Anderson is on show with some of her most well-known and energised works to date. Featuring William S. Burroughs as himself with his introduction to Sharkey’s Night, Won-Sang and Sang-Won Park delivering dialogue accompanied with traditional Japanese instrument, the kayageum, “Home of the brave” presents a poetic collaboration of Western and Asian aesthetics with ‘attitude’. Other musicians include: Joy Askew, Adrian Belew, David Van Tieghem, Richard Landay, Richard Landry IV, Dolette McDonald and Janice Pendarvis.
